title: NC Tutorial 3 (en)

{"title":"NC Tutorial 3 (en)","nodes":{"0":{"type":"Notes","name":"TUTO 3","x":28,"y":25,"ins":[],"inNames":[],"outNames":[],"params":{"text":"       ---------------------------
      | First Steps in NoiseCraft |
       ---------------------------

Some exercises in manipulating and exploring NoiseCraft functions (or 'nodes').

Move around the main window and the notes using the scroll bars.

All the nodes used in these exercises can be created by clicking on the bottom of the page and selecting them from the list. However, in this first tutorial, the focus will be on manipulating pre-existing nodes.


The notes associated with the exercises tell you more about the functionality of these nodes and about the theory of sound synthesis and music theory in general. These theories can be learned and refined later.

---------------------

0","x":29,"y":268,"ins":[],"inNames":[],"outNames":[],"params":{"text":"1. Create a 'Delay' node at the bottom right of the 'Mul (ADSR)' and connect its input to the output of this 'Mul'.

2. Create a couple of 'Mul' and its knob named 'vol' (connected to the 'in1' input of the 'Mul' of course) to the right of the 'Delay' so that you can control the volume of the Delay.

3. Connect the output of the Delay to the 'in0' of the 'Mul' and the output of the 'Mul' to the 'in1' of the 'Add' so that you can add what comes out of the 'Delay' to the initial sound.

4. Create a button named "time" below the Delay and connect it to the 'time' input of the Delay.

5. By double-clicking on the title of the "Time" button, set its value to 0.25

Test the synthesizer...

Modify the value of the 'time' by setting it to 0.375 for example"}},"15":{"type":"Mul","name":"Mul","x":1682,"y":280,"ins":[["13",0],["16",0]],"inNames":["in0","in1"],"outNames":["out"],"params":{}},"16":{"type":"Knob","name":"OUT VOL","x":1674,"y":353,"ins":[],"inNames":[],"outNames":[""],"params":{"minVal":0,"maxVal":1,"value":1,"deviceId":null,"controlId":null}},"20":{"type":"Mul","name":"Mul (ADSR)","x":1180,"y":280,"ins":[["12",0],["4",0]],"inNames":["in0","in1"],"outNames":["out"],"params":{}},"26":{"type":"Notes","name":"Rem 0","x":29,"y":469,"ins":[],"inNames":[],"outNames":[],"params":{"text":"If the Delay volume = 1 all the sounds produced will obviously have the same volume. This allows you to simply double all the notes at a certain rate.

A delay of 0.25 = 1/4 [s]. If the tempo is 120 bpm, then each of the first three notes (which are after the thicker black lines) are played on the beat every 0.5 = 1/2 [s]. In other words, the notes played (doubled by the delay) are exactly half the interval of the notes played on the beats. These are called backbeats.

If the same effect is desired with tempi other than 120 bpm, then the length of the delay must be adjusted accordingly. This can be automated with a little programming, but suppose we want to do it manually for a tempo of 100 BMP, then we have to calculate the length of the beat = 60[s]/100[bpm] = 0.6 [s]. A delay on the backbeat will therefore have a value of 0.6/2 = 0.3 [s]. Try it out!

Finally, as you have seen, if another note than the one played by the delay is on the counter-time (like here the fourth note (G3), then a C3+G3 chord start will be produced at that moment."}},"27":{"type":"Pulse","name":"Pulse 1","x":35,"y":767,"ins":[],"inNames":[],"outNames":[],"params":{"text":"1. Be careful not to make the wrong connections!

2. Connect the 'out' output of the 'Delay' to the 'in0' input of the lowest 'Mul (FB)'. The produced delay will be amplified to 75% of its original volume. 

3. Connect the output of this 'Mul (FB)' to the 'in1' input of the 'Add (FB)'. This will create a feedback loop which will be added to the signal entering the 'Delay'.

Test the synthesizer..."}},"47":{"type":"Notes","name":"Rem 1","x":36,"y":968,"ins":[],"inNames":[],"outNames":[],"params":{"text":"You'll notice first of all how pleasant this Feedback Delay is, with a 25% = 1-0.75 volume drop on each loop.

You will also notice that the length of the delay is interesting: 0.375 [s] for notes played every second. With the effect of feedback, notes will be played at times 0; 0.375; 0.375 + 0.375 = 0.75; 0.75 + 0.375 = 1.125; 1.125 + 0.375 = 1.5, etc.

these intervals are interesting and "natural", because they correspond to 3/8; 6/8; 9/8; 12/8; etc. of a second.

In other words, if the second is considered to be worth a quarter note, then the eighth note = 1/2 is worth 0.5 [s] and the sixteenth note = 1/4 is worth 0.25 [s] and the sixteenth note = 1/8 is worth 0.125 [s]. The Delay thus produces certain intervals worth triple eighth notes, while keeping the quarter note accentuation on the beats.


Note also that a 'Pulse' set to vary between 0 and 1 has been used here in LFO mode at a frequency of 1 [Hz]. Its 'pw' (power) is set to 0.9, i.e. the wave = 0 for the first 0.9 * 1[s] seconds and 1 for the remaining 0.1 seconds. The 'Slide' node allows to soften the brutal curve of this 'Pulse' by a certain rate in order to be used to give a volume envelope to the Pulse playing the frequency 110."}},"48":{"type":"Notes","name":"Ex 2","x":25,"y":1351,"ins":[],"inNames":[],"outNames":[],"params":{"text":"1. Be careful not to make the wrong connections!

2. Start by selecting the node sequence 'Add (L)'-'Delay +(0.25)'-'Mul +(Feedback)' and copy it.

3. Paste it down about the same distance from the 'Mul (ADSR)'.

4. Rename the bottom 'Add(L)' to 'Add(R).

5. Connect the output of the 'Mul (ADSR) to the 'in1' input of 'Add(R)' and the output of the 'Mul (FB)' of this series of nodes to the 'in1' input of 'Add All (R)'.

6. Change the 'time' of the Delay from below to 0.375 [s].

By doing this, you have created two delays of different values for the left and right channels of your 'AudioOut'.

Now you need to connect the feedbacks so that they produce feedback, but how?

7. Connect the output of the 'Mul (FB)' from below to the 'in1' input of the 'Add (L)' from above.

8. Connect the output of the 'Mul (FB)' from above to the 'in0' input of the 'Add (R)' from below.

Listen to the result!"}},"62":{"type":"ADSR","name":"ADSR","x":1163,"y":1491,"ins":[["95",1],["64",0],["65",0],["65",0],["66",0]],"inNames":["gate","att","dec","sus","rel"],"outNames":["out"],"params":{}},"63":{"type":"Add","name":"Add pe":"Const","name":"Const","x":1604,"y":2080,"ins":[],"inNames":[],"outNames":[""],"params":{"value":0.16666666}},"229":{"type":"Const","name":"Const","x":1762,"y":2206,"ins":[],"inNames":[],"outNames":[""],"params":{"value":0.5}},"231":{"type":"Notes","name":"Ex 3","x":38,"y":1899,"ins":[],"inNames":[],"outNames":[],"params":{"text":"1. Test the synthesizer!

2. Consider the sixteenth notes of the sequencer. As in Ex 1, create between the two neutral nodes 'Fx(In&Out)' a Delay = sixteenth note/3 with a feedback 0.5. Use constants (node 'Const').

(the answer of the calculation is at the end of the remark)"}},"232":{"type":"Notes","name":"Rem 3","x":39,"y":2101,"ins":[],"inNames":[],"outNames":[],"params":{"text":"Here the reverberation is produced by filtered delays of very short duration. 

If you are placed right next to the sound source, then if a reverberant wall is placed 5m away from you, the sound produced by the sound source will travel 10m = 5m+5m before coming back reverberated to your ears. As the speed of sound is 340.29 [m/s], then the delay will be 10/340.29 [s].

The filter subtraction used here is used to select the reverberated frequencies. The feedback with an "average" varying between 1.2 and 2 allows to simulate new echoes, but less strong on walls placed at the same distance.

Finally, the other 'Delay', placed after the reverb, but on the 'R' (right) channel, allows to simulate a different (bigger) space on the right side of the listener.


Answers calculations Ex 3:

Since BPM = 30, then quarter note = 60[s]/30 = 2[s]
eighth note = quarter note/2 = 1[s]
sixteenth note = eighth note/2 = 0.5[s]
Delay time = 0.5/3 = 1.66666666666[s]"}},"237":{"type":"AudioOut","name":"AudioOut","x":1827,"y":269,"ins":[["15",0],["15",0]],"inNames":["left","right"],"outNames":[],"params":{}}}}
